channel.title: On Matthew's Mind... (sometimes this is always good stuff)
channel.description: On Matthew's Mind... (sometimes this is always good stuff)

item.title: No title
item.description: The latest Tweets from On Matthew's Mind (@matty_neu). Unapologetic Christian, Intrapreneur, Family Man, CrossFitter, Kansas Jayhawks fan & Financial advice giver. Grateful co-founder of two powerhouse boys. Kansas

item.title: Thin Slicing
item.description:
Thin Slicing

My boys love French toast. Bread, butter, powdered sugar, the works if we let 'em. Saturday mornings kick start the best when Noah & Evan get tried-and-true French toast to fuel the weekend! And when mom, dad or a restaurant prepares their French toast, we don't need anything fancy.

item.title: Hard Work (in perspective)
item.description:
Hard Work (in perspective)

What we do everyday isn't hard work. At 4 am today I greeted the Kansas City airport parking maintenance man. He was doing hard work. The line cook at McDonald's I see arriving at 5 am to prep burgers, that's hard work.

item.title: Money Makes You...
item.description:
Money Makes You...

One of my top clients, and now closest friends, is crossing over our 10 year anniversary working together. She's an inspiration to me in a lot of ways - professional and personal. First and foremost, thank you Sandy. Thank you for choosing me, for choosing us, and for leaning into our relationship this last decade.

item.title: Perception & Reality
item.description:
Perception & Reality

An old boss used to tell me "perception is reality". I hate that. Even worse, in showing his true (lack of) character, most times the next thing said was "a lie stuck to is as good as the truth." I'm not making this up.

item.title: Marketing Manager
item.description:
Marketing Manager

Does this make sense to you? Someone spends $100,000, $200,000 or $300,000 a year to market new clients into their firm. But when I ask basic marketing return on investment, cost of client acquisition and budgeting questions, they're at a loss for words. Why? Because they're "too busy" to know.

item.title: Let 'Em Loose
item.description:
Let 'Em Loose

Some families show up at my son's school looking perfect. Kid's hair styled, shoes cleaned, stains removed. And while I can appreciate those families, more power to 'em... That's not us. Our boys are overly-loved and very well cared for.
